channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Reports of Atrocities in Ukraine Spur Outrage
item.description: The devastating toll of the war became clearer as Russian forces withdrew from around Kyiv. World leaders promised more sanctions.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Widespread destruction across Bucha, Ukraine, on Sunday, after Ukrainian forces had allegedly targeted a Russian convoy.

item.title: Imran Khan Dissolves Parliament, Blocking No-Confidence Vote
item.description: Imran Khan’s actions have set up a constitutional battle over the country’s leadership. The Supreme Court is expected to address the turmoil on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Pakistan’s ruling party chanting anti-American slogans in Islamabad on Sunday.

item.title: ‘This Is True Barbarity’: Life Under Russian Occupation
item.description: The town of Trostyanets was occupied by Russian forces for a month before the Ukrainian military liberated it. Residents described weeks of hunger and horror.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Trostyanets, Ukraine, was held by the Russian military for roughly 30 days before the Ukrainian military retook it on March 26.

item.title: Taliban Outlaw Opium Poppy Cultivation in Afghanistan
item.description: The move will have far-reaching consequences for the many farmers who turned to the illicit crop as a brutal drought and economic crisis have gripped the country.
item.dc:creator: Safiullah Padshah and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Farmers harvesting opium from poppies last year in Maiwand, Afghanistan.

item.description: The government wants Thailand’s capital to be known around the world as Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok). Thais don’t object to the name, but they’d prefer their leaders focus on fixing the economy.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A giant statue of Buddha looking over Bangkok or, as it is commonly known in Thai, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon.

item.title: With Ukraine War, Viktor Orban Softens His Embrace of Russia
item.description: Facing an election on Sunday, Viktor Orban plays neutral peacemaker while campaigning against the “gender insanity” that he says is creeping in from the West.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Benjamin Novak
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary in Szekesfehervar on Friday during his party’s final rally before the election on Sunday.

item.title: Pope Francis Alludes to Putin’s Role in War on Ukraine
item.description: Francis’ remarks during a trip to Malta were the closest he has come to pinning the war in Ukraine on President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Andreas Solaro/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President George Vella of Malta, center right, and his wife, Miriam, greeted Pope Francis after he landed on the island on Saturday.

item.title: Yemen’s Warring Parties Begin First Cease-Fire in 6 Years
item.description: The two-month truce, brokered by the United Nations, offers hope for a reduction of violence in a war that has rattled the Arabian Peninsula and caused a humanitarian crisis.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Mohammed Huwais/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Forces loyal to the Houthi rebels taking part in a military parade on Thursday in Sana, the Yemeni capital. The parade marked the seventh anniversary of the Saudi-led coalition’s intervention in Yemen.

item.title: In Shanghai, Covid Is Separating Parents From Children
item.description: As China’s largest city struggles to contain a coronavirus outbreak, outrage erupted online after images circulated of small children isolated from parents.
item.dc:creator: John Liu and Paul Mozur
item.media:credit: Aly Song/Reuters
item.media:description: Residents lining up last weekend for coronavirus tests outside a Shanghai hospital.

item.title: Why Madrid Rivals Miami as a Haven for Latin Americans
item.description: Turmoil and a political swing to the left have brought an influx of prominent and affluent exiles from the region to the Spanish capital in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cafe overlooking the Plaza de Cibeles in Madrid. For wealthy Latin Americans, one businessman noted, the Spanish capital offers attractive investment opportunities.

item.title: In Brazil, Firms Sought Black Workers. Then LinkedIn Got Involved.
item.description: After Brazilian activists fought LinkedIn for removing job ads that sought Black and Indigenous candidates, the company changed its global policy.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Raphael Vicente, general director of the Business Initiative for Racial Equality, in São Paulo. His initiative promotes affirmative action policies.

item.title: Israeli Troops Kill 3 Palestinian Militants in West Bank
item.description: The Israeli authorities said the men were killed in a shootout. The security forces have ramped up their operations after a wave of violence.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Mohamad Torokman/Reuters
item.media:description: Israeli troops on patrol in Jenin, in the West Bank, on Wednesday.

item.title: War in Ukraine Compounds Hunger in East Africa
item.description: The conflict has driven up the cost of food in a region that depends heavily on crops from Russia and Ukraine and is facing what could be its worst drought in four decades.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Farah Abdi Warsameh/Associated Press
item.media:description: People in Somalia who fled drought-stricken areas arrive at a makeshift camp on the outskirts of the capital, Mogadishu, in February. The drought has left nearly a third of the country’s population hungry.

item.title: Living With Gusto Despite a Rare, Fatal Disease, and Hunting for Answers
item.description: At 26, Sammy Basso is believed to be the oldest person with the disease Progeria. And now he’s researching it, hoping to find a treatment and the secrets of aging.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sammy Basso training with his runners club, a group of friends and fans who run marathons to support progeria awareness.

item.title: Ukraine’s President Zelensky Gives Emotional Speech at the Grammys
item.description: The Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelensky, made a plea for support before John Legend performed, sharing the stage with a poet and a singer from Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Julia Jacobs
item.media:credit: Rich Fury/Getty Images
item.media:description: “Our children draw swooping rockets, not shooting stars,” Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukrainian president, said in video that was broadcast during the Grammys on Sunday night.

item.title: Pro-Putin Leaders in Hungary and Serbia Set to Win Re-election
item.description: Viktor Orban declared victory, and Serbia’s Aleksandar Vucic seemed likely to emerge on top. Both pledged to stay out of Russia’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Benjamin Novak
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban after declaring victory on Sunday in Budapest, Hungary.

item.title: In a Kyiv Suburb,‘They Shot Everyone They Saw’
item.description: With Russian forces retreating, Ukrainians in Bucha are finding scores of bodies in yards and on the roads amid mounting evidence of intentional and indiscriminate killings of civilians.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Widespread destruction could be seen across Bucha, Ukraine, a suburb northwest of Kyiv where Russian forces recently withdrew.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Reports of Russian Atrocities
item.description: Graphic images of civilian deaths may shift international diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: There was widespread destruction across Bucha. In this area the damage had allegedly been done after Ukrainian forces had targeted a Russian convoy, using Turkish made attack drones, in the early stages of the war.

item.title: Taliban Take On a Treacherous, Avalanche-Prone Pass
item.description: After overthrowing the government, the Taliban are now trying to save what’s left of the roads they spent years blowing up, with none more critical than a two-mile-high pass through the Hindu Kush.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Yaqoob Akbary and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: Russia Committed ‘Apparent War Crimes,’ Human Rights Watch Says
item.description: The organization’s report is based on a series of interviews with eye witnesses, victims and local residents of Russia-occupied territories between Feb. 27 and March 14.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers from the Azov battalion in Bucha, a town northwest of Kyiv, where footage showed scattered bodies and widespread destruction on the streets on Saturday.

item.title: Opposition Leaders Accuse Pakistan’s Imran Khan of High Treason
item.description: Shehbaz Sharif, the leader of the opposition, said Prime Minister Imran Khan had violated the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Anjum Naveed/Associated Press
item.media:description: Opposition leader Shahbaz Sharif, left, arriving at the National Assembly in Islamabad on Sunday.

item.title: Images of Dead Civilians in Bucha Draws Outrage From U.S. and Others
item.description: Russia’s Ministry of Defense called the images “staged,” saying in a statement that “not a single” civilian had been injured in the town.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov, Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Constant Méheut, Aurelien Breeden, Emily Cochrane and Cassandra Vinograd
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers from the Azov battalion walk through the remnants of a Russian military convoy in Bucha, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Cabinet Resigns as Protesters Defy Government Curfew
item.description: The midnight resignations, amid an escalating economic crisis, leave only the president, Gotabaya Rajapaksa, and his brother, the prime minister, in a cabinet that has been dominated by their family.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Emily Schmall
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally in Colombo, the Sri Lankan capital, on Sunday.

item.title: Why Some Foreign Volunteers Are Joining the Military in Ukraine
item.description: Ukraine has created a foreign legion, inviting foreigners with military experience to come and join the fight against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Will, 33, left, a former U.S. Marine from North Carolina, and Luis, 29, a veteran of the Mexican Army, are volunteering to join the fight against Russian forces.

item.title: Supreme Court Says It Will Weigh in Monday on Pakistan Turmoil
item.description: Opposition leaders have asked the court to allow a no-confidence vote to go forward, which would reignite efforts to oust the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of PTI chanting anti-American and anti-opposition slogans outside the National Assembly in Islamabad on Sunday.

item.title: Documentary Filmmaker Mantas Kvedaravicius Is Killed in Ukraine
item.description: Mr. Kvedaravicius, 45, had spent years covering the conflict in Ukraine. His work included “Mariupolis,” a searing portrait of the southern port city where he died.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Snapshot Photography/Ullstein Bild via Getty Images
item.media:description: The documentary filmmaker Mantas Kvedaravicius.

item.title: Rodrigo Chaves on Track to Become Costa Rica’s New Leader
item.description: Preliminary results showed Rodrigo Chaves with a big lead over José María Figueres, who conceded. Mr. Chaves has pledged to overhaul the political system that turned Costa Rica into a model of stability.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and David Bolaños
item.media:credit: Ezequiel Becerra/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rodrigo Chaves in San José, Costa Rica, last week.

item.title: Climate Optimism
item.description: We have reason for hope on climate change.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Adrienne Surprenant/Associated Press
item.media:description: Children reflected in stagnant water after flooding in South Sudan last year.

item.title: Who Is Imran Khan, Pakistan’s Prime Minister?
item.description: He was once a national hero who led Pakistan’s cricket team to a World Cup victory. Now, the embattled prime minister is fighting to stay in power.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Imran Khan at his residence in Islamabad, Pakistan, in 2019.

item.title: How Microplastics in the Ocean Will Affect Marine Life
item.description: Tiny bits of plastic have infiltrated the deep sea’s main food source and could alter the ocean’s role in one of Earth’s ancient cooling processes, scientists say.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler

item.title: Why is the prime minister in trouble?
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Imran Khan last month. Pakistan has been gripped by a political crisis after he appeared to lose support from the military and a coalition of opposition parties moved to vote him out of office.

item.title: ‘Macbeth’ performances on Broadway pause after Daniel Craig tests positive for the coronavirus.
item.description: The show, which just began previews on Tuesday, hopes to resume on April 8.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: Daniel Craig, left, and Ruth Negga in “Macbeth” at the Longacre Theater in New York.

item.title: Hochul Says Second Boosters Are Offered at New York Vaccination Sites
item.description: Government officials move to get ahead of an uptick in cases fueled by the highly transmissible Omciron subvariant.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Giang
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: A New York City mobile vaccine clinic parked on Central Park South on Wednesday.

item.title: Lithuania Says It Has Stopped Importing Gas From Russia
item.description: Although tiny, Lithuania is the largest economy in the Baltic States and a eurozone member, giving the decision significance to European nations. “If we can do it, the rest of Europe can do it too,” the president said.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Ints Kalnins/Reuters

item.title: When the Russians Picked the Wrong Town in Ukraine to Invade
item.description: The outgunned people of Vasylkiv, a provincial Ukrainian town, successfully fought off Russian troops in the early days of the war, helping to keep the capital safe and entering Ukraine’s military lore.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of the Territorial Defense Force, Ukraine’s volunteer forces, on the outskirts of Vasylkiv earlier this week. Ukrainian forces kept Russian troops at bay there in the early days of the war.

item.title: Imran Khan Says He Won’t Accept Result of No-Confidence Vote
item.description: The prime minister of Pakistan, whose coalition has lost support in the National Assembly, claimed the coming vote was a conspiracy between opposition lawmakers and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:credit: Anjum Naveed/Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Imran Khan at a military parade in Islamabad last month. Abandoned by coalition partners, he faces a no-confidence vote on Sunday.

item.title: Positive Covid Tests Reach Record Levels in England and Wales
item.description: Britain’s Office of National Statistics reported the trend, and estimated that almost 4.4 million people in England and Wales had been infected in a single week.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:credit: Vickie Flores/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Commuters at Liverpool Street Station in London last month.

item.title: Russia Retreats From Kyviv, Seeking to Regroup from Battering
item.description: A short drive from Kyiv in any direction turned up scenes of incinerated Russian vehicles, charred engine parts and chunks of armor. Attention is now shifting to the east, where Moscow says it is redirecting its forces.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers inspecting the remains of a Russian military vehicle on the road outside of Kyiv on Saturday.

item.title: Is Russia Quitting the International Space Station? Not Quite.
item.description: NASA has sidestepped suggestions that Russia might pull out of the space station partnership.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: Irina Spektor/Roscosmos Space Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Russian Soyuz space capsule landed in Kazakhstan, on Wednesday, carrying three astronauts: Mark Vande Hei of NASA with Anton Shkaplerov and Pyotr Dubrov of Russia.

item.title: For Putin, the Invasion Is Another Failure in Ukraine
item.description: Beginning in 2004, the Russian leader’s repeated efforts to subjugate his neighbor have been defeated, frustrating his imperial ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Maxim Shemetov
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at a ceremony in Volgograd in 2018 marking the 75th anniversary of the battle of Stalingrad.

item.title: The ‘China Model’ is being tested by Covid, Russia and the economy. And it’s coming up short.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Quarantine workers in Shanghai after the city was locked down in mid-March.

item.title: President Biden asks for more funding and Hong Kong’s death toll strains mortuaries: The week in Covid news.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden receiving his second booster shot of a Covid vaccine at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: Mandates are ending in the U.S., but protests outside officials’ homes continue.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:credit: Craig F. Walker/The Boston Globe, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mayor Michelle Wu of Boston passing a small group of demonstrators as she left her home in the Roslindale neighborhood of the city in January.

item.title: Ukrainian Photojournalist Who Went Missing Near Kyiv Is Found Dead
item.description: Maks Levin, 40, was a prominent freelancer who had spent years covering the conflict in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: Torrey Peters’s Inspirations
item.description: The author of “Detransition, Baby” on Scandinavian literature and croissants.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: How Catholics Avoided Paying Millions in Reparations in Canada
item.description: During its final weeks in office, the previous Conservative government reached a deal allowing the church to walk away from most of its obligations.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Guglielmo Mangiapane/Reuters
item.media:description: The president of the Métis National Council, Cassidy Caron, second from left, with other Indigenous delegates.

item.title: On Its Way to the U.S., Russian Oil Tanker Makes Giant U-Turn
item.description: The ship, originally sailing to Philadelphia, apparently lost its buyer in the middle of the Atlantic. A number of tankers carrying Russian oil face similar problems.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi and Blacki Migliozzi
item.media:credit: Bjoern Kils/Reuters
item.media:description: The tanker Minerva Virgo docked in New York last month after leaving Russia in February. It was met with protesters from Greenpeace.

item.title: U.S. Will Help Transfer Soviet-Made Tanks to Ukraine
item.description: The transfer, a response to a request from Ukraine’s president, will mark the first time the Biden administration has helped send tanks in the five-week-old war.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Soviet-made tanks will allow Ukraine to conduct long-range artillery strikes on Russian targets in the eastern Donbas region, an American official said.

item.title: Two New Jersey High Schools Reinstate Mask Mandates After Covid Outbreak
item.description: New coronavirus cases have led to the resumption, if temporarily, of some mitigation strategies.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.category: South Brunswick High School (Monmouth Junction, NJ)
item.media:credit: Google Maps
item.media:description: South Brunswick High School in central New Jersey reinstated its mask mandate on Friday.

item.title: Zelensky Calls for Popular Disobedience, in Both Ukraine and Russia
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine threatened retribution for people who collaborate with occupying forces and accused retreating Russians of planting mines and even booby-trapping corpses.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv on Friday, before a meeting with Roberta Metsola, the president of the E.U. Parliament.

item.title: The case of four men accused of plotting to kidnap Michigan’s governor over Covid rules goes to the jury.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Nick Hagen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The men planned to kidnap Gov. Gretchen Whitmer from her vacation home in Michigan, prosecutors said.

item.title: Spike in Violence Poses Test for Israel’s Fragile Government
item.description: A rash of terrorist attacks has spawned criticism of the government from the left and right, and for opposite reasons. But the coalition’s diversity has constrained its options.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Oded Balilty/Associated Press
item.media:description: Right-wing activists protesting against Prime Minister Naftali Bennett in Tel Aviv this week.

item.title: Charles G. Boyd, Air Force General and Former P.O.W., Dies at 83
item.description: He began his 36-year career in the military as a fighter pilot and was the only prisoner of war in the Vietnam conflict to become a four-star general.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: With cases rising, Mayor Eric Adams is keeping New York City’s preschool mask mandate.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.media:credit: Stephanie Keith for The New York Times
item.media:description: “You should keep your masks on your children,” Mayor Eric Adams said, reversing plans to remove a school mask mandate for children under 5 amid a rise in coronavirus cases.

item.title: Budi Tek, 65, Dies; His Fortune Built a Vast Trove of Asian Art
item.description: He was one of the world’s top collectors, and his immense Yuz Museum in Shanghai helped establish the region’s bustling art scene.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Bertrand Rindoff Petroff/Getty Images)
item.media:description: The billionaire art collector Budi Tek in 2012. He specialized in what he called mega-art, like the work behind him: Adel Abdessemed’s “Telle Mer, Tel Fils” (“Like Mother, Like Son”), consisting of three full-scale airplanes intertwined.

item.title: Russia’s Aggression Prompts Calls to Rethink U.S. Uranium Imports
item.description: The war in Ukraine has highlighted the risks of U.S. dependence on Russia for the fuel needed for nuclear energy, creating new challenges for the industry.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague

item.title: U.N. Says Yemen’s Warring Parties Have Agreed to 2-Month Truce
item.description: The agreement comes after a significant escalation in recent weeks that saw Yemen’s Iran-backed Houthi rebels claim several attacks.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Mohammed Huwais/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The aftermath of airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen’s capital, Sanaa, last month.

item.title: Europe Asks China Not to Aid Russia’s War in Ukraine
item.description: A first E.U.-China summit in two years was overshadowed by Ukraine and China’s alliance with Moscow and produced few results.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Tingshu Wang/Reuters
item.media:description: The E.U.-China summit shown in Beijing on Friday.

item.title: Fires, Then Floods: Risk of Deadly Climate Combination Rises
item.description: A new study found that the dangerous pairing of disasters may become more common in the American West as rains trigger runaway surges of mud and debris in areas damaged by wildfire.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Noah Berger/Associated Press
item.media:description: People helped a neighbor retrieve belongings from a home damaged in a mudslide in Salinas, Calif., in January 2021.

item.title: Turkey Moves Closer to Ending Khashoggi Murder Trial Without Conclusion
item.description: Turkey’s justice minister said he would agree to transfer the trial to Saudi Arabia, effectively ending a case that rights groups hoped could offer a measure of justice.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger/Reuters
item.media:description: A candlelight vigil for Jamal Khashoggi in front of the Saudi Embassy in Washington in 2019.
